paper_id: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments

paper_metadata.title: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments
paper_metadata.primary_focus: Potassium balance in long-term field experiments under different fertilization treatments

research_methodology.experimental_design: Six fertilization treatments applied to a three-crop rotation (potatoes-winter wheat-spring barley), with all three crops grown each year. Experiments conducted at two sites with different soil and climatic conditions.

temporal_scope.data_collection_frequency: Annually for plant harvest; soil samples collected at study initiation (1996) and end (2017).
temporal_scope.seasonal_coverage: Autumn for organic and mineral P/K application; Spring for mineral N application (potatoes, spring barley); divided N application for winter wheat (BBCH 21, BBCH 31–32).
monitoring_timeline: 2017 (End of 7th crop rotation, final soil sampling, plant harvest)

site_characteristics: Hněvčeves: Haplic Luvisol on loess, Clay loam texture, 265 m a.s.l.
Humpolec: Stagnic Cambisol on loess on paragneiss, Sandy loam texture, 525 m a.s.l.
spatial_scope.regional_representativeness: Corresponds with intensive farming systems used in the Czech Republic.

sample_design.randomization_approach: Not explicitly stated, but implied by 'trials were established'.
controls_and_treatments: Half dose of farmyard manure + nitrogen (N) in mineral nitrogen fertilizers (FYM 1/2)
Straw of spring barley + N in mineral nitrogen fertilizers (N + ST)

measurement_protocols: Plant K content: Dry decomposition (Mader et al. 1998), Atomic Adsorption Spectrometry (AA280FS, Agilent Technologies).
Soil K content (bioavailable): CaCl2/DTPA (CAT) extraction (CSN EN 13651, 2001) - 3.00 g soil + 30 mL 0.01 mol/L CaCl2 and 0.002 mol/L DTPA, shaken 1h, filtered.

Soil K content (bioavailable): Mehlich 3 extraction (Mehlich 1984) - 3.00 g soil + 30 mL 0.02 mol/L CH3COOH, 0.25 mol/L NH4NO3, 0.015 mol/L NH4F, 0.013 mol/L HNO3, 0.001 mol/L EDTA, shaken 5 min, filtered.
Soil K content (exchangeable): Ammonium acetate (NH4OAc) extraction (modified Haby et al. 1990) - 3.00 g soil + 30 mL 1 mol/L ammonium acetate (pH 7.00), shaken 2h, centrifuged.

Soil K content (non-exchangeable): Boiling HNO3 extraction (Helmke and Sparks 2000) - 2.5 g finely ground soil + 25 mL 1 mol/L HNO3, heated 10 min after boiling, cooled 5 min, filtered, diluted to 100 mL with 0.1 mol/L HNO3. Non-exchangeable K determined by subtracting NH4OAc-determined K from HNO3 values.
instrumentation: Atomic Adsorption Spectrometry (AA280FS, Agilent Technologies, Mulgrave, Australia)
Optical Emission Spectrometer with Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP-OES, Agilent Technologies 700, Victoria, Australia)

statistical_approach.significance_testing: Not explicitly detailed, but 'significant differences' are reported.
statistical_approach.uncertainty_quantification: Not explicitly detailed for all reported values.

primary_measurements.parameter: K recovery rate from farmyard manure by crops
K recovery rate from mineral fertilizers by crops

primary_measurements.measurement_context: Luvisol site: 850 mg K ne/kg; Cambisol site: 3000 mg K ne/kg (no change recorded at Cambisol site)
Mineral nitrogen fertilization treatment at Humpolec site

primary_measurements.parameter: Average K uptake by plants (Humpolec vs Hněvčeves)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Humpolec higher by 348 kg K/ha on average for all variants over 21 years

primary_measurements.parameter: Potassium content in plough layer (Mehlich 3) at 2017 (approximated from Figure 1)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Hněvčeves: Control ~161, FYM 1 ~292, FYM 1/2 ~203, N ~166, NPK ~216, N + St ~174; Humpolec: Control ~122, FYM 1 ~214, FYM 1/2 ~155, N ~123, NPK ~186, N + St ~143

primary_measurements.parameter: Exchangeable potassium content in plough layer (NH4OAc) at 2017 (approximated from Figure 2)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Hněvčeves: Control ~168, FYM 1 ~296, FYM 1/2 ~206, N ~170, NPK ~219, N + St ~179; Humpolec: Control ~122, FYM 1 ~214, FYM 1/2 ~155, N ~123, NPK ~186, N + St ~143

variables: Content of exchangeable K in soil

statistical_relationships.significance_level: Clear tendency to higher K utilization at soils with higher sorption capacity

temporal_patterns.trend_description: Changes recorded only at Luvisol site, not at Cambisol site.
temporal_patterns.trend_significance: Significant at Luvisol, not significant at Cambisol

comparative_results.statistical_significance: Not explicitly stated, but 'higher' is used.
comparative_results.practical_significance: Higher K uptake at Humpolec despite lower bioavailable K, possibly due to higher precipitation and distribution.

comparative_results.statistical_significance: Not explicitly stated, but clear differences shown.
comparative_results.practical_significance: Positive K balance only with manure; highest negative balance with mineral N fertilization.

geographic_details.elevation: Hněvčeves: 265 m a.s.l.; Humpolec: 525 m a.s.l.

climate_characteristics.climate_classification: Not explicitly stated, but characterized by temperature and precipitation.

precipitation_patterns.distribution_Humpolec: Regular distribution throughout the vegetation period

climate_characteristics.growing_season: Implied by crop rotation and annual growth.

soil_properties.soil_classification: Hněvčeves: Haplic Luvisol on loess; Humpolec: Stagnic Cambisol on loess on paragneiss
soil_properties.texture: Hněvčeves: Clay loam; Humpolec: Sandy loam
soil_properties.mineralogy: Clay minerals of 2:1 types, mica and vermiculite (relevant for non-exchangeable K binding).

land_use_context.management_intensity: Varied by fertilization treatments (no fertilization to NPK, organic, straw incorporation).
sustainability_metrics: Changes in exchangeable and non-exchangeable K in soil

production_metrics.K_content_in_plants: Measured for grain, straw, and tubers

types: Mineral nitrogen fertilizers (calcium ammonium nitrate, 27% N)
Mineral phosphorus fertilizers (triple super phosphate, 21% P)

rates.total_N_3_year_cycle: 330 kg N/ha (for FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N+St)

timing: Organic fertilizers (FYM, straw): Autumn (October) to potatoes.
Mineral P and K fertilizers: Autumn to each crop.
Mineral N fertilizers: Spring prior to crop establishment (potatoes, spring barley).
Mineral N fertilizers (winter wheat): Divided into halves (BBCH 21, BBCH 31–32).

data_collection_schedule: Soil sampling at study start (1996) and end (2017)
study_timeline.monitoring_frequency: Annual for yields, biennial for soil (implied by start/end sampling for detailed analysis).

long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Different fertilization intensities manifested by significant differences in exchangeable K content, indicating long-term impact on soil K reserves.

long_term_trends.trend_direction: Changes recorded at Luvisol site, no changes at Cambisol site
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Highlights site-specific differences in K dynamics and potential for K deficit under insufficient K fertilization.

long_term_trends.trend_direction: Mostly negative, except for FYM treatment
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Indicates unsustainable K management in most treatments, leading to K deficit in agricultural soils, especially given low annual mineral K doses in CR.

variability_characterization.inter_annual_variability: Yields and K uptake varied between sites, influenced by climatic conditions (precipitation).
variability_characterization.spatial_variability: Significant differences between Hněvčeves and Humpolec sites in soil properties, climate, yields, and K dynamics.
variability_characterization.measurement_uncertainty: Not explicitly quantified for all measurements.

methodological_strengths: Long-term study (21 years) providing valuable insights into long-term K dynamics.
Conducted at two sites with contrasting soil and climatic conditions, enhancing generalizability.
Comprehensive analysis of different K forms (bioavailable, exchangeable, non-exchangeable).
Inclusion of various fertilization treatments, including organic and mineral sources.
Use of established and recognized analytical methods (Mehlich 3, NH4OAc, Boiling HNO3, ICP-OES).
methodological_limitations: Detailed soil analyses (1996 vs 2017) were only based on samples from spring barley plots, potentially limiting representativeness for other crops in rotation.
Initial soil K values (Mehlich 3, NH4OAc) are not explicitly presented in figures, only the final state, making direct before-after comparison from figures challenging.
Specific cultivar information for crops is not provided.
Standard errors or confidence intervals are not consistently provided for all reported numerical values (e.g., yields, K content in plants).
data_quality_assessment.data_completeness: High for K balance, soil properties, and fertilization rates. Moderate for detailed statistical outputs (e.g., p-values for all comparisons).

representativeness.spatial_representativeness: Good, with two distinct sites representing intensive farming systems in the Czech Republic.
representativeness.temporal_representativeness: Excellent, due to the 21-year study duration.
representativeness.system_representativeness: Good, reflecting common crop rotation and fertilization practices in the region.

uncertainty_sources: Approximation of values from bar graphs (Figures 1 and 2).
Inherent variability in field experiments due to environmental factors.
Potential for unmeasured factors influencing K dynamics.
validation_evidence: Findings on K utilization and sorption capacity are consistent with previous research (Blake et al. 1999).
The importance of non-exchangeable K for plant availability is supported by Liu and Bates (1990).

comparative_studies: Blake et al. (1999) on K utilization and sorption capacity.
Liu and Bates (1990) on the information content of non-exchangeable K for plant availability.
literature_integration.theoretical_framework: Potassium dynamics in soil, including soil solution, exchangeable K, and non-exchangeable K; plant K uptake mechanisms, including rhizosphere acidification.
benchmarking_data: Annual potassium doses in mineral fertilizers in the Czech Republic (5–6 kg K/ha agricultural soil for more than 20 years).

extraction_metadata.data_richness_assessment: The paper is rich in methodological details, quantitative results for K balance, soil properties, and crop yields across different treatments and sites over a long period.
potential_ambiguities: Exact numerical values for bar graphs (Figures 1 and 2) were approximated visually.
Initial soil K values for Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc methods are mentioned as analyzed but not explicitly presented in the provided figures, which only show the final state.
extraction_limitations: Lack of specific cultivar names for crops.
Absence of detailed statistical outputs (e.g., p-values for all comparisons, standard errors for all means) for some reported values.
quality_flags: Values from Figure 1 and Figure 2 are approximated from the graphs.
recommended_validation_checks: Verify approximated graph values if original data or more precise figures become available.

results.paper_id: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments.pdf
